--- title: "Hertie Coding Club" subtitle: "Session 3: (Re) Introduction to R" author: - name: Jorge Roa margin-header: hertie_logo.png opts_chunk: R.options: width: 10 backgorund-color: #FFFFFF; #title-slide-attributes: # data-background-size: 10% # data-background-position: 100% 100% # data-background-image: HCC-HD.png format: revealjs: title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: images/hertie_logo.png data-background-size: 15% data-background-position: 2% 2% data-background-color: steelblue color: #517699; slide-number: c/t multiplex: true width: 1600 height: 750 #height: 1000 logo: images/logo_hcc_bk.png footer: "Session 3: (Re) Introduction to R" css: [assets/syntax-highlight.css, assets/custom.css, assets/pacman.css] transition: fade transition-speed: fast margin-bottom: 1px theme: default echo: true highlight-style: "dracula" #{style="float:right;text-align:right;"} For specific --- # Agenda for today {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 2.5em;"}
# Agenda for today {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}

::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Little introduction - Recap from the second session - Base R and Tidyverse - Wrangle dataframes ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: # Dataframes {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .8em;"} Example ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - We will work with Airbnb accommodation data in Berlin as of September 15, 2022. They are open data available at [Airbnb: get the data](http://insideairbnb.com/get-the-data.html). - They are open data licensed under the Creative Commons CC0 1.0 Universal "Public Domain Dedication. - Those who stay can choose between entire houses/apartments, only private rooms, or shared rooms (room_type). - After the stay, they must leave an evaluation (review). - Accommodations vary in price, a minimum number of days of stay, days available, etc. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Airbnb_Logo_B%C3%A9lo.svg/2560px-Airbnb_Logo_B%C3%A9lo.svg.png){fig-align="center" height="150"} ![](images/airbnb){fig-align="center" height="400"} ::: ::: # Import dataframes from your computer {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .8em;"} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} How we import data? ![](https://findicons.com/files/icons/2795/office_2013_hd/2000/excel.png){fig-align="center" height="50"} Excel files Quite frequently, the sample data is in Excel format, and needs to be imported into R prior to use. ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} library(readxl) df_listings <- read_xlsx("data/listings.xlsx") ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: ::: # What do we want to find out from this data? {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .8em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} First, I ask myself questions, then think about the code that answers them. - What are the variables? How many? - How many observations do you have? - What values do these variables take? - Is there missing data? Are there duplicate cases? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Explore the data ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} View(df_listings) ``` ::: OR (Best option: only works with dataframes) CTRL + click on your object (IN YOUR SCRIPT). ![](images/view.png){fig-align="center" height="350"} ::: ::: # Explore the data {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .8em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} The dim(), names(), and str() functions take a data frame as an argument. ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} dim(df_listings) # dimension of the dataframe ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 16680 75 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} nrow(df_listings) # rows ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 16680 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} ncol(df_listings) # columns (variables) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 75 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} names(df_listings)[1:10] # variable names ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "id" "listing_url" "scrape_id" [4] "last_scraped" "source" "name" [7] "description" "neighborhood_overview" "picture_url" [10] "host_id" ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} #str(df_listings) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Explore the data ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} max(df_listings$price) #maximum value. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4375 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} median(df_listings$price) #median. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 65 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} min(df_listings$price) #minimum value. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} mean(df_listings$price) #mean. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 96.30809 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} var(df_listings$price) #variance. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 13638.87 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} sd(df_listings$price) #Standard deviation. ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 116.7856 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: # Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .8em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Load the Berlin listings_berlin.xlsx file. - Calculate the mean, median, and variance of the variables minimum_nights, number_of_reviews, and last_review. Then, store those results in different vectors and create a dataframe with them. Name the dataframe with `df_exercise_1` ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}




::: ::: # Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .8em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Upload the Berlin listings.csv file. - Calculate the mean, median, and variance of the variables minimum_nights, number_of_reviews, and last_review. Then, store those results in different vectors and create a dataframe with them. Name the dataframe with `df_exercise_1` - Why get NA in the variance of the last_review variable? - It's a string. We can't apply numerical function to strings. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} v_mean_minimum_nights <- mean(df_listings$minimum_nights) v_mean_number_of_reviews <- mean(df_listings$number_of_reviews) v_mean_last_review <- mean(df_listings$last_review) v_med_minimum_nights <- median(df_listings$minimum_nights) v_med_number_of_reviews <- median(df_listings$number_of_reviews) v_med_last_review <- median(df_listings$last_review) v_var_minimum_nights <- var(df_listings$minimum_nights) v_var_number_of_reviews <- var(df_listings$number_of_reviews) v_var_last_review <- var(df_listings$last_review) df_exercise_1 <- data.frame(mean = c(v_mean_minimum_nights, v_mean_number_of_reviews, v_mean_last_review), median = c(v_med_minimum_nights, v_med_number_of_reviews, v_med_last_review), variance = c(v_var_minimum_nights, v_var_number_of_reviews, v_var_last_review)) df_exercise_1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` mean median variance 1 12.11559 3 1530.456 2 27.76787 6 3881.410 3 NA NA NA ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: # Working Directory {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 2.5em;"}
# Working Directory {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - It refers to the files that are on the computer - `getwd()` : returns the path of the working directory. R works by default in certain folder called working directory where you will read and save the files. - `setwd()` : defines the working directory, to modify it. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} - 🆘 **It is not recommended that the correct execution of the syntax depend on a specific path...** 🆘 `dir()` : displays the files that are in the working directory - R does not understand  (with backslash the paths are written in Windows) - Paths in R are defined with / and it is also valid to use `\\`
::: ::: # Base R and Tidyverse: %\>% pipe operator {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size:1.5em;"}
# Base R and Tidyverse: %\>% pipe operator {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} `%>%` comes from the `magrittr` package. It takes the output of one function and passes it into another function as an argument. With pipes, your workflow will be much better.
`%>%` equals to a "then". If we read `%>%` as “then”, the code will be very easy to digest for us. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} Let's say that you have your object `day`. ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} my_day <- go_to_school(brush_my_teeth(take_shower(wake_up(Jorge)))) ``` ::: Now with the `%>%` operator ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} my_day <- Jorge %>% wake_up() %>% take_shower() %>% brush_my_teeth () %>% go_to_school() ``` :::
::: ::: # Shortcut: %\>% pipe operator {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} WINDOWS ![](images/windows_short.png){fig-align="center" height="350"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} MAC ![](images/mac_short.png){fig-align="center" height="350"}
::: ::: # Base R and Tidyverse: %\>% pipe operator {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
Limitations ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Remember that our "then" chains functions in a logical (linear) order, the `%>%` is less applicable to objects/problems that include multidirectional relationships. - We can do just one object at a time. - It doesn’t work with certain functions of packages (don't worry) that use the current environment, nor functions that use lazy evaluation. For our purpose, the pipe operator will be our best friend. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](https://cdn-icons-png.flaticon.com/512/7490/7490434.png){fig-align="center" height="350"}
::: ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size:1.5em;"}
# Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
select() function:Select specific variables of our dataframe. Base R ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_select_baser <- df_listings[c("bedrooms", "beds", "price")] ``` :::
Dyplr without pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_select_dplyr1 <- select(df_listings, bedrooms, beds, price) ``` :::
Dplyr with pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_select_dplyr_pipe <- df_listings %>% select(bedrooms, beds, price) ``` ::: # Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Select the variables price, bedrooms and beds. Then save the dataframe as df_price and give the mean of the price.
Hint: remember our `$` operator for dealing with dataframes. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: # Exercise {background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Select the variables price, bedrooms and beds. Then save the dataframe as df_price and give the mean of the price.
Hint: remember our `$` operator for dealing with dataframes. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_price <- df_listings %>% select(price, bedrooms, beds) mean(df_price$price) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 96.30809 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
select() function: With this function, we can also drop variables. Base R ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_drop_baser <- subset(df_listings, select = -c(id, scrape_id, source, description)) ``` :::
Dyplr without pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_drop_dplyr1 <- select(df_listings, -id, -scrape_id, -source, -description) ``` :::
Dplyr with pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_drop_dplyr_pipe <- df_listings %>% select(-id, -scrape_id, -source, -description) ``` ::: # Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Drop the variables `host_neighbourhood`, `host_picture_url`, `host_is_superhost` and `reviews_per_month.` I want you to use two ways: with and without pipe. Give me the dimensions of the dataframe before we drop the variables. Then, after dropping our variables, give me the dimensions again of the dataframe
Hint: remember how we need to put our objects without the pipe Hint2: to get the dimensions of our dataframe, is with the dim() function. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: # Exercise {background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Drop the variables `host_neighbourhood`, `host_picture_url`, `host_is_superhost` and `reviews_per_month.` I want you to use two ways: with and without pipe. Give me the dimensions of the dataframe before we drop the variables. Then, after dropping our variables, give me the dimensions again of the dataframe
Hint: remember how we need to put our objects without the pipe Hint2: to get the dimensions of our dataframe, is with the dim() function. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} dim(df_listings) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 16680 75 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} #Dyplr without pipe df_drop_wo_pipe <- select(df_listings, -host_neighbourhood, -host_picture_url, -host_is_superhost, -reviews_per_month) #Dplyr with pipe df_drop_with_pipe <- df_listings %>% select(-host_neighbourhood, -host_picture_url, -host_is_superhost, -reviews_per_month) dim(df_drop_with_pipe) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 16680 71 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"} filter() function: With this function, we can also filter variables. Base R ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_baser <- subset(df_listings, host_location == "Berlin, Germany") ``` ::: Base R (other way) ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_baser_2 <- df_listings[which(df_listings$host_location == "Berlin, Germany"), , drop = FALSE] ``` ::: Dyplr without pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_dplyr1 <- filter(df_listings, host_location == "Berlin, Germany") ``` ::: Dplyr with pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_dplyr2 <- df_listings %>% filter(host_location == "Berlin, Germany") ``` ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"} Filter two or more variables Base R ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_2_baser <- subset(df_listings, host_location == "Berlin, Germany" & room_type == "Private room") ``` ::: Base R (other way) ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_2_baser_2 <- df_listings[which(df_listings$host_location == "Berlin, Germany" & df_listings$room_type == "Private room"), , drop = FALSE] ``` ::: Dyplr without pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_2_dplyr1 <- filter(df_listings, host_location == "Berlin, Germany" & room_type == "Private room") ``` ::: Dplyr with pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_2_dplyr2 <- df_listings %>% filter(host_location == "Berlin, Germany" & room_type == "Private room") ``` ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Filter two or more variables (numeric) Base R ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_3_baser <- subset(df_listings, price >= 10 & price <= 50) ``` ::: Base R (other way) ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_3_baser_2 <- df_listings[which(df_listings$price >= 10 & df_listings$price <= 50), , drop = FALSE] ``` ::: Dyplr without pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_3_dplyr1 <- filter(df_listings, price >= 10 & price <= 50) ``` ::: Dplyr with pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_filter_3_dplyr2 <- df_listings %>% filter(price >= 10 & price <= 50) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
![](https://bookdown.org/ndphillips/YaRrr/YaRrr_files/figure-html/comparison-1.png){fig-align="center" height="350"}
::: ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Other examples Filter the dataframe by price: I want airbnbs that cost greater than or equal to 30 OR that cost less than or equal to 50 ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_or_price <- df_listings %>% filter(price >= 30, price <= 50) ``` ::: Filter the dataframe by price: I want airbnbs that doesn't cost 30 euros. ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_or_price <- df_listings %>% filter(price != 30) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
![](https://bookdown.org/ndphillips/YaRrr/YaRrr_files/figure-html/comparison-1.png){fig-align="center" height="350"}
::: ::: # Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1.- Use the `availability_30` variable and select the rooms that have more than 3 days and less than or equal to 10 days. Once you have that filtered the dataframe, give me the median of that variable. Hint: You can use the approach (Base R, or pipeline) to do the exercise
2.- Use the `beds` variable and select the rooms that have less than 3 beds ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: # Exercise {background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1.- Use the availability_30 variable and select the rooms that have more than 3 days and less than or equal to 10 days. Once you have that filtered the dataframe, give me the median of that variable. Hint: You can use the approach (Base R, or pipeline) to do the exercise
2.- Use the beds variable and select the rooms that have less than 3 beds ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_exercise <- df_listings %>% filter(availability_30 > 3 & availability_30 <= 10) dim(df_exercise) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1917 75 ``` ::: ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_exercise_2 <- df_listings %>% filter(beds < 3) dim(df_exercise_2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 13763 75 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: # Dataframe functions (Base R and dplyr) {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"} ::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} mutate() function: With this function, we can create new variables variables. Base R ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_listings$new_variable <- df_listings$beds + df_listings$accommodates ``` ::: Dyplr without pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_mutate <- mutate(df_listings, new_variable = beds + accommodates) ``` ::: Dplyr with pipe ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_mutate_dplyr_pipe <- df_listings %>% mutate(new_variable = beds + accommodates) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
![](https://i0.wp.com/makemeanalyst.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Arithmetic-Operator-1.png?resize=505%2C345){fig-align="center" height="350"}
::: ::: # Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1.- Select the variables `price` and `beds`. Then, create a new variable with the rate between the `price` and `beds` vairable. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: # Exercise {background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1.- Select the variables `price` and `beds`. Then, create a new variable with the rate between the `price` and `beds` vairable. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_mutate <- df_listings %>% select(price, beds) %>% mutate(rate = price/beds) ``` ::: ::: ::: # Final Exercise {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .7em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1.- Select the variables beds, accommodates, price, bedrooms, host_location, availability_30, minimum_nights and maximum_nights. Pipe this operation and 2.- Filter the beds variable and select the rooms that have more than 3 beds OR less than or equal to 10 beds. Pipe this and 3.- Filter the host_location to just show the location of the host that are in Berlin. Pipe this and finally 4.-Create two new variables. One called min_night_price with the prices that you would pay if you stay the minimum nights. 5.-And anohter variable called rate_bed which is how many beds we have per bedroom. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: # Final Exercise {background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: .7em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} 1.- Select the variables beds, accommodates, price, bedrooms, host_location, availability_30, minimum_nights and maximum_nights. Pipe this operation and 2.- Filter the beds variable and select the rooms that have more than 3 beds OR less than or equal to 10 beds. Pipe this and 3.- Filter the host_location to just show the location of the host that are in Berlin. Pipe this and finally 4.-Create two new variables. One called min_night_price with the prices that you would pay if you stay the minimum nights. 5.-And anohter variable called rate_bed which is how many beds we have per bedroom. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell .height_auto} ```{.r .height_auto .cell-code} df_exercise_final <- df_listings %>% select(beds, accommodates, price, host_location, availability_30, minimum_nights, maximum_nights, bedrooms) %>% filter(beds > 3, beds <= 10, host_location == "Berlin, Germany") %>% mutate(min_night_price = price * minimum_nights, rate_bed = beds/bedrooms) ``` ::: ::: ::: # Workspace / Environment {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size:1.5em;"}
# Workspace / Environment {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-in-out" background="linear-gradient(to top, #48c6ef 0%, #6f86d6 100%)" style="text-align: left; font-size: 1em;"}
::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - It is located in RAM memory. - The collection of objects generated in a session. - ls() to get the list of objects stored in RAM. - To remove objects you can use the rm() command. - When closing Rstudio they are lost, but we have the syntax to recreate them :) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
